variant.question: The human information processing system is highly efficient compared to computers because of its

options.text: flexibility.
speed.
independence from attention.
working memory capacity.

variant.question: An aircraft is performing an approach to aerodrome A in bad weather in an executive aircraft. The conditions mean the pilot must divert to aerodrome B. However, the passenger, who is part of senior management in your company, insists that the pilot lands at aerodrome A. What could this be an example of if the pilot is conditioned to obey authority and continue the approach to aerodrome A?

options.text: National culture overriding the safety culture.
Complacency on the part of the pilot and impulsivity on the part of the passenger.
Resignation.
Anti-authority.

variant.question:
You are transporting a passenger who has to be at a certain destination for a meeting
The weather forecast at destination tends to be much worse than expected, so you consider to divert
The businessman offers you money if you manage to land there at any case
What is your appropriate way of action? You will

options.text: decide to divert if you think it is necessary.
see what you can do and ask the copilot to tolerate any decision.
continue and think about the nice things you can buy for the money.
divert in any case to demonstrate who is the man in charge aboard.

variant.question: The assessment of risk in a particular situation will be based on

options.text: subjective perception and evaluation of situational factors.
the emergency checklist only.
external factors only.
situational factors only.

variant.question: A transport category aircraft flies into a developing tropical country. Select from the options below the correct statement.

options.text: The operator should have procedures for the regular application of insecticides inside the aircraft to avoid the spread of malaria and yellow fever.
Drinking of tap water should be avoided, ice cubes should be used in drinks. Pilots should make sure to consume sufficient amounts of fresh fruit and vegetables for a nutritious diet.
Pilots should consider eating meat and fish for possible contamination with worms and fruit and vegetables because of bacterial contamination.
All pilots should carefully make sure that they have current vaccination against malaria, yellow fever, typhoid and Cholera.

variant.question:
An aircraft is on approach when the tower controller instructs the cockpit crew to perform a go-around, because an aircraft on the ground has just entered the landing runway. The pilots immediately start to perform their go-around manoeuvre, the pilot flying advancing the thrust levers and increasing pitch, the pilot monitoring setting the go-around path active on the FMS and expecting the configuration changes to be requested. The tower controller then addresses the aircraft again, saying that a go-around is no longer required.
Which of the following is most likely to happen?

options.text: Neither pilot will consciously receive the radio message, because both of them will be too focused on performing the flight manoeuvre.
The pilot monitoring will be distracted by the radio call, his attention would be drawn away from monitoring the instruments.
The pilot flying will take over the task of monitoring the flight instruments, while the pilot monitoring concentrates on the radio call.
Both pilots will briefly discuss whether the go-around can still be aborted and a landing can be made.

variant.question: Decision-making is a concept which represents:

options.text: a voluntary and conscious process of selection, from among possible solutions, for a given problem
an automatic process of selection from among the various solutions to a given problem
an automated or automation-like act of applying defined procedures
a spontaneous act of seeking the most effective solution in a given situation when faced with a defined problem

variant.question: Decision-making is a concept which represents:

options.text: a voluntary and conscious process of selection, from among possible solutions, for a given problem.
a spontaneous act of seeking the most effective solution in a given situation when faced with a defined problem.
an automatic process of selection from among the various solutions to a given problem.

variant.question: In order to make sound decisions it is important to

options.text: understand why and how we make decisions.
avoid situational awareness.
accept that the Captain, because of his/her authority, tends to be correct.

variant.question: With regard to the DECIDE model, which answer is not correct?

options.text: “E” means “Error” and is included to give room for a change in plans should the actions taken not have the desired effect.
“D” means “Detect”. You first have to realise that a condition exists which forces you to react.
“E” means “Evaluate (the effects of the action)”. You must not forget to monitor the effects of your decision and assess whether further correction is required.
“D” means “Do (the necessary action)”. This is the time to carry out the required steps.

variant.question: With regard to the DECIDE model, which answer is not correct?

options.text: “C” means “cross-check”. It advises you to supervise the effects of your actions in order to react to undesired outcomes.
“D” means “Detect”. You first have to realise that a condition exists which forces you to react.

“E” means “Estimate” and is included to allow for the fact that some undesired conditions may have effects that are so negligible that they do not deserve the amount of attention (and resource) they receive.
“I” means “Identify actions needed to achieve the chosen option”. It tells you to find out what you have to do to obtain the desired result.

variant.question: A bias is a tendency that can prevent open-minded decision making.Which of the following is an example of a bias in aeronautical decision making?

options.text: Confirmation bias: the tendency to search for information that confirms one’s preconceptions.
Impulsivity bias: a tendency to make immediate decisions without considering other options.
Anti-authority bias: a tendency to disregard rules, regulations, and view procedures as unnecessary.
Resignation bias: a tendency to lack confidence in one’s own abilities during crises.

variant.question:
A flight is made in severe weather conditions with the following flight crew composition:
The newly upgraded captain has a total flight time of 5 200 hours, most of which is on the type currently flown. His copilot, who has just recently joined the company, has a total flight time of 15 000 hours. Previously, he has been flying similar aircraft types. The copilot is currently pilot flying (PF), the captain is pilot monitoring (PM). On final approach, the DH is passed and sufficient visual contact cannot be made. The copilot continues the approach with the words “I will make it”; the captain does not react.
Which statement is correct according to composition?

options.text: A mismatch of role and status occurred.
The crew basically displayed good CRM, but miscommunication occurred.
The captain should not question his more experienced colleague during final approach, but should have been more helpful providing data.
The roles have been correctly assigned and discussed during the preflight briefing, but the captain should have acknowledged.

variant.question: What are the main sources of error in a pilot's decision-making mechanism?

options.text: Situation assessment and its associated level of risk; selection of the appropriate course of action.
Identification of tactical actions in the given situation; anticipating the consequences of the available options.
Biases affecting unprejudiced decison making; external factors such as peer pressure and group behaviour.
Determination of the situational risk or hazard; assessment of the environmental circumstances.

an authoritarian approach thus demonstrating ones own ability to lead
the improvement of internal risk assessment capabilities
a fast and decisive option
the suggestion of a sequential solution in which everyone can contribute what he/she knows.

variant.question: Open-minded aeronautical decision making can be prevented by biases. Name one of the most important decision making biases.

options.text: Confirmation bias: a tendency to seek or distort information to confirm one’s existing perception.
Anti-authority bias: A tendency to make decisions in deliberate disregard of rules and regulations and to view procedures as unnecessary.
Resignation bias: a tendency to lack confidence in one’s own abilities in critical situations.
Impulsivity bias: a tendency to select the first or most obvious solution without searching for better options.

variant.question:

The pilots did not follow the checklist for this specific issue

variant.question: What is meant by "risky shift"?

options.text: The tendency of a group accepting a higher degree of risk than any individual in the group.
A flight or task undertaken at a time when the circadian rhythms are at their point of lowest efficiency.

variant.question:
Consider the following scenario during the initial approach phase of a commercial flight into an airfield situated in mountainous terrain:
1) The pilots notice that information from two engine instruments does NOT agree.
2) Both pilots are fully focused on analysing the problem.
3) The weather is VMC and there is a lot of light and heavy aircraft traffic in the area.
4) The ETA is 30 minutes behind schedule, endangering a timely departure for the next leg.
Considering the theories and models of human error, to ensure the safety of the flight, what should the pilots do at this point?

options.text: An error chain might be developing: preventative actions should be taken to manage the threats and errors.
The pilots should continue to focus their attention on the problem while they proceed to the destination for landing.
This might just be an isolated case of an engine indication error. Because the pilots are not sure they should ignore the indication until after landing.
The pilots should contact ATC and request advice on how to proceed.

options.text: A good decision depends on analysis of the situation.

variant.question: An experienced pilot is flying on schedule and on time, the weather is above the minima for the destination airport. Suddenly, the visibility dropped below the minima and the pilot decided to continue the approach and at the end landed safely. What can explain why the pilot did not divert and decided to land without the required minima?

options.text: They were anxious to land on time and wanted to avoid getting behind schedule for the next flight.
Due to his/her experience, he/she was sure that weather would have improved again.
Since they landed safely, there is no problem.
The pilot knew that they could operate safely in the reduced visibility.

variant.question:
The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) of an aircraft is inoperative. There are no ground-start facilities available at the aerodrome, but the APU is necessary to start the engines. Therefore, one engine is kept running while the aircraft is refueled, and ground serviced. The temperature is around 0ºC and a light snow is falling. De-icing treatment is permitted only with engines off. If all the engines are shut down, the aircraft can only be re-started once the APU is repaired. 
 To depart from the airport as planned, the Commander decides not to de-ice. A few minutes after take-off, the aircraft develops ice-formation on the wings and consequently, it stalls. 
  
 Which of the following statements most correctly explains the decision-making of the Commander?

options.text: The Commander fails to properly evaluate his/her options before take-off by underestimating the risk of ice formation during flight and/or ignoring the influence of ice contamination on aircraft performance.
The Commander properly assesses the situation and evaluates the options correctly, giving priority to the aircraft departing on time and minimizing inconvenience to the passengers.

The Commander has made a good assessment of the situation but takes too much time to reach a decision. As a result, the risk of ice contamination increases, along with a reduction in aircraft performance.
The decision to depart is good, but the Commander fails to review the decision once they have taken-off by ignoring the influence of ice contamination on aircraft performance.

variant.question:
Which of the following describes good pre-planning and anticipation?
1. On conducting a twin engine aircraft pre-flight, the commander notices an oil leak but decides NOT to have a maintenance engineer look at it. 
 2. There is a full load of passengers and fuel. The flight is to depart at midday. The temperature is slightly higher than forecast. The Commander re-does the performance calculations and decides to delay the departure. 
 3. During a VFR flight, approaching high ground, the cloud base is lower than forecast. There is insufficient fuel to divert around and the flight must remain VFR. The Commander decides to turn back.

options.text: Only 2.
Only 3.
1 and 2.
2 and 3.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning decision making and biases is correct?

options.text: Confirmation bias is a tendency to give undue weight to information supporting the current mental picture.
Attentional bias occurs when the entire crew simultaneously focuses on one particular aspect while at the same time ignoring other important details.
Biases tend to differ among crew members and thus can help finding more probably solutions to a problem and improve the quality of the final decision if managed wisely.
Routine bias can help crews to find the most adequate solution quickly in conditions of high workload.

variant.question: What statement is correct as regards the pilots' attention during the following scenario and the risks associated with it? A go-around has already been initiated, when ATC delivers a long message, changing the missed approach procedure.

options.text: The attention of the Pilot Not Flying could be diverted from the task of monitoring the aircraft parameters, which can lead to a loss of awareness of the aircraft's state.

The ATC communication will probably be ignored, because the attention of the Pilot Not Flying is fully concentrated on monitoring the aircraft's parameters and checking the go-around procedures, while the Pilot Flying is fully engaged in controlling the aircraft.

Listening to the ATC instruction could divert the Pilot Flying's attention from the task of controlling the aircraft. The Pilot Flying should be able to carry out both tasks successfully, because a go-around is a routine procedure.

The Pilot Not Flying (PNF) copies and acknowledges the ATC instructions, while the Pilot Flying (PF) takes over the PNF's monitoring duties. Because of the additional tasks performed, the PF can suffer from cognitive overload.

variant.question:
An aircraft operating with the FMS in the VNAV/LNAV mode is operating in a busy terminal area at the end of a flight. Bad weather in the area has resulted in ATC requiring the flight crew to make several changes to the aircraft's flight path.
In order to maintain the maximum awareness of their flight status, what is the best action for the pilots to take?

options.text: Re-programming of the FMS in the VNAV/LNAV mode during periods of high workload can lead to errors and also cause a loss of situational awareness. Therefore, the pilots should downgrade to a lower, simpler level of automation such as ALT/HDG or even to manual flying.

The FMS in VNAV/LNAV mode is the primary, and most accurate, navigation system available to the pilots, and its use should be maintained. In order to minimise data entry errors, both pilots should check the entry of the new VNAV/LNAV parameters at the same time.

The main risk is that the pilots become distracted while re-programming the FMS. To reduce this risk, the Pilot-in-Command should immediately request a short delay or a hold, in order to complete the entry of the new VNAV/LNAV parameters, before continuing with the approach.

In order to mitigate against loss of situational awareness, and avoid the risk of errors while entering new data, the FMS should be switched off, and the pilots should respond to ATC instructions by flying the aircraft manually.

variant.question:
An aircraft operating with the FMS in the LNAV VNAV mode is operating in a busy terminal area at the end of a flight. Bad weather in the area has resulted in ATC requiring the flight crew to make several changes to the aircraft's flight path. 
  In order to maintain the maximum awareness of their flight status, what is the best action for the pilots to take?

options.text: Re-programming of the FMS in the LNAV VNAV mode during periods of high workload can lead to errors and also cause a loss of situational awareness. Therefore, the pilots should downgrade to a lower, simpler level of automation such as ALT/HDG or even to manual flying.

The FMS in LNAV VNAV mode is the primary, and most accurate, navigation system available to the pilots, and its use should be maintained. In order to minimise data entry errors, both pilots should check the entry of the new LNAV/VNAV parameters at the same time.

The main risk is that the pilots become distracted while re-programming the FMS. To reduce this risk, the Pilot-in- Command should immediately request a short delay or a hold, in order to complete the entry of the new LNAV VNAV parameters, before continuing with the approach.

In order to mitigate against loss of situational awareness, and avoid the risk of errors while entering new data, the FMS should be switched off, and the pilots should respond to ATC instructions by flying the aircraft manually.

Infallibility

variant.question: With regard to the DECIDE model..

options.text: 'I' means 'Identify actions needed to achieve the chosen option?. It tells you to find out what you have to do to obtain the desired result.
'D' means 'Diet'. It reminds you that a balanced diet is required to be fit to fly.
'E' means 'Error' and is included to give room for a change in plans should the actions taken not have the desired effect.
'C' means 'cross-check'. It advises you to supervise the effects of your actions in order to react to undesired outcomes.

variant.question: With regard to the DECIDE model..

options.text: “I” means “Identify actions needed to achieve the chosen option”. It tells you to find out what you have to do to obtain the desired result.
“E” means “Error” and is included to give room for a change in plans should the actions taken not have the desired effect.
“C” means “cross-check”. It advises you to supervise the effects of your actions in order to react to undesired outcomes.
“D” means “Diet”. It reminds you that a balanced diet is required to be fit to fly.

variant.question: With regard to the DECIDE model..

options.text: “D” means “Detect”. You first have to realise that a condition exists which forces you to react.
“I” means “Illness”. It reminds you that diseases, as well as non-prescription or prescription drugs taken can make you unfit to fly.
“E” means “Error” and is included to give room for a change in plans should the actions taken not have the desired effect.
“C” means “cross-check”. It advises you to supervise the effects of your actions in order to react to undesired outcomes.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding decision making?

options.text: Deciding means choosing between alternatives.
Deciding means imposing one’s point of view.
Deciding means applying an automatic procedure.
Deciding means being able to come up with original solutions

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding decision making?

options.text: Deciding means choosing between alternatives.
Deciding means being able to come up with original solutions.
Deciding means imposing one’s point of view.
Deciding means applying an automatic procedure.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding decision making?

options.text: Deciding means choosing between alternatives.
Deciding means being able to come up with original solutions.
Deciding means imposing one's point of view.
Deciding means applying an automatic procedure.

variant.question: With regard to the DECIDE model, which answer is incorrect?

options.text: “C” means “cross-check”. It advises you to supervise the effects of your actions in order to react to undesired outcomes.
“D” means “Detect”. You first have to realise that a condition exists which forces you to react.
“I” means “Identify actions needed to achieve the chosen option”. It tells you to find out what you have to do to obtain the desired result.

“E” means “Estimate” and is included to allow for the fact that some undesired conditions may have effects that are so negligible that they do not deserve the amount of attention (and resource) they receive.

variant.question: The choice of the moment you select flaps depending on situation and conditions of the landing is

options.text: skill and/or rule based behaviour.
pressure based behaviour.
knowledge based behaviour.
always automated behaviour.
